pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the `zetaDelta` configuration option to `ring_nf` and `abel_nf`, so that users can control whether local let variables are unfolded. It is set to false by default. Prior to this PR it was set to true.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e65cb358aa](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21194/commits/e65cb358aa8ed0b399fa672f0f50fa021fa0113b)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

From the test I found out that in `ring_nf` I forgot to add the `zeta_delta` to the context of the `simp` call. So for both tactics, the `zetaDelta` is set in both the `simp` context and the `MetaM` context.

When making the last fix, I found a bug in `ring_nf` with the `AtomM` monad, which is used to keep track of atoms. The problem is that bound variables can go in and out of scope, and then the `isDefEq` comparison that compares two atoms can throw an "unknown free variable" error. So the `isDefEq` should really be wrapped in a `try ... catch _ => pure false`.

Shall I make a separate PR for this?
@JovanGerb yes, you should make a separate PR for that bug.
Why is the default value of this paramter changing? do we have evidence that setting it to false should be preferred? Is there some Zulip discussion?

Here is a message claiming that `zetaDelta := false` is the preferred setting: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/239415-metaprogramming-.2F-tactics/topic/whnf.20variant.20which.20preserves.20let-bindings/near/482733494

I think the reasoning is the same as for `simp`, which also got the default `zetaDelta := false`. It gives people more control to hide the definitions of let variables from these tactics (otherwise there isn't much point in having the local let variables). It seems natural that if you want it to see through the let variables, then you explicitly unfold them.
I don't understand this test, should the first `!`  be deleted?
Yes it should
Does this do anything? the `ctx` is already being passed into `Simp.main` a few lines above.
There are also a (`withReducible`) `whnf` and `isDefEq` that aren't influenced by the `simp` configuration. I think it is reasonable to also have those in the appropriate `zetaDelta` configuration.
Similarly, should this (also?) be set on line 138 when the `ctx` is created?

I don't think the position matters. The only MetaM function that this would influence is `Lean.Meta.SimpTheorems.addConst`, which is applied on some fixed constants.
If you prefer, I'm happy to move it to the beginning of the function.
I was describing just the change you already made above.

pullRequest.title: feat(Tactic): add `zetaDelta` option to `ring_nf` and `abel_nf` and change default to `false`

source.title: feat: stop `ring`/`abel` from seeing algebraic operations inside lets

nodes.body: From the test I found out that in `ring_nf` I forgot to add the `zeta_delta` to the context of the `simp` call. So for both tactics, the `zetaDelta` is set in both the `simp` context and the `MetaM` context.

When making the last fix, I found a bug in `ring_nf` with the `AtomM` monad, which is used to keep track of atoms. The problem is that bound variables can go in and out of scope, and then the `isDefEq` comparison that compares two atoms can throw an "unknown free variable" error. So the `isDefEq` should really be wrapped in a `try ... catch _ => pure false`.

Shall I make a separate PR for this?
@JovanGerb yes, you should make a separate PR for that bug.
Why is the default value of this paramter changing? do we have evidence that setting it to false should be preferred? Is there some Zulip discussion?

Here is a message claiming that `zetaDelta := false` is the preferred setting: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/239415-metaprogramming-.2F-tactics/topic/whnf.20variant.20which.20preserves.20let-bindings/near/482733494

I think the reasoning is the same as for `simp`, which also got the default `zetaDelta := false`. It gives people more control to hide the definitions of let variables from these tactics (otherwise there isn't much point in having the local let variables). It seems natural that if you want it to see through the let variables, then you explicitly unfold them.
